posts.name: Cameron (Advanced Programmer)
posts.cooked:
We got back from champs and we had to figure out how to set this new radio up for use at home. Here are the steps we used since the docs didn’t make it super clear for us.

These are not the official vivid hosting documentation but these are .

Note: Step 5 could be completed first.

Step One Unplug/Power down the radio

Step Two Remove the sticker from the back of the radio covering the dip switches. IMG_20240424_191638 1920×2560 295 KB

IMG_20240424_191638 1920×2560 295 KB

IMG_20240424_191638 1920×2560 295 KB

Step Three Flip dip switch 3 to the on position. (This will allow the robot to make an access point) IMG_20240424_191616 1920×1440 235 KB

IMG_20240424_191616 1920×1440 235 KB

IMG_20240424_191616 1920×1440 235 KB

Step Four Plug in and boot your radio

Step Five Plug in your pc to the DS port and go to http://10.XX.YY.1 in a web browser (in the event that your radio has no team number it should be ip address 192.168.69.1). Then ensure that you are in “Robot Radio Mode”, your team number is correct, and assign two WPA Keys (one for 6ghz connection and one for 2.4ghz access point) and “configure” the radio (We just entered our team number twice with no spaces).  Once the settings are applied you may need to reboot your radio. IMG_20240424_191916 1920×2560 378 KB

IMG_20240424_191916 1920×2560 378 KB

IMG_20240424_191916 1920×2560 378 KB

Step Seven You should be able to connect to your robot under the wifi name FRC -XXYY with the password you assigned under WPA key for 2.4ghz access point.

link_counts.title: VH-109 FRC Radio | English | FIRST FRC Radio

posts.name: Domenico
posts.cooked:
You should be able to connect to your robot under the wifi name FRC -XXYY with the password you assigned under WPA key for 2.4ghz access point.

Does that mean that we cannot use the 6ghz at home?

posts.name: Cameron (Advanced Programmer)
posts.cooked: You can, however it will require another device to do so. The Vivid hosting documentations says that the radio is not FCC approved for using a 6ghz access point while plugged into a battery. I believe you would have to use the robot radio as a 6ghz client and connect to another radio/device that hosts a 6ghz access point. We will be working on setting something like this a little later in the off season.
So I can’t rename my team’s robot’s network to BEANS anymore?

posts.name: Cameron (Advanced Programmer)
posts.cooked: I guess not It would be cool if they added it in a firmware update. We often have more than one robot running at a time and would find it useful to give them names.

posts.name: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)
posts.cooked:
I pieced this together last night with their documentation but this is a good writeup of the process we followed.  Also, I had to look for a second to confirm dipswitches.

Dipswitches #1 = Aux 1 #2 = Aux 2 #3 = 2.4Ghz

posts.name: mikets
posts.cooked: Just got the new radio a couple days ago and decided to set it up today. I followed the instructions and successfully set up the radio with our team number, switched ON dip switch 3 and saw the 2.4 GHz Wifi SSID in “Robot Radio” mode. Everything is hunky-dory until I decided to also update the firmware to 1.1.2. Downloaded the new firmware, selected the file, specified the SHA-256 and clicked upload. A little while later, it said “Failure”. Tried again several times and still got failure. So, I decided to power cycle the radio. Then I no longer see the radio. Dig a little deeper and found the radio reverted its IP address to 192.168.1.1 (not 192.168.69.1). Connected to it from a web browser showed me a OpenWrt login page with the user name “root”. I tried several typical root passwords but was not able to login. Now I wish there is a reset button or pin hole that will reset the darn thing back to manufacturer default. How do I get the radio back to working order?

posts.name: Cameron (Advanced Programmer)
posts.cooked: With the limited knowledge of the community seems like contacting Vivid Hosting directly may be the best option.

posts.name: mikets
posts.cooked: I was hoping @kiettyyyy would reply since he is Vivid Hosting. The Vivid Hosting website doesn’t have any “support” or “contact” link. So, I have no idea how to contact them directly.

posts.name: Kiet Chau
posts.cooked:
Hmm.

Could you reach out to WCP ?

They will RMA the radio for you. We’d love to get a hold of this again for failure analysis.

posts.name: David Kravets
posts.cooked: Hi, our team is trying to run our second VH-109 as a 6ghz broadcast antenna for robot testing. We can’t seem to get the 6ghz antenna/broadcast to turn on. The 6ghz led lights up briefly at boot and then goes dim. We have the dip switches set to the proper settings as per the docs, not really sure where to go from here. Some help would be much appreciated

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked: How are you powering the AP?  Referring to LED Status Indications , are you seeing “Solid Power, Blinking SYS, 2.4G, 6G lights (20 Hz)”?

link_counts.title: LED Status Indications | FIRST FRC Radio

posts.name: David Kravets
posts.cooked: It’s powered using the VividHosting PoE adapter. We see solid power and solid sys light on the access point radio, no other lights are on

posts.name: David Kravets
posts.cooked:
Update, our radio SSID didn’t seem to be configured correctly. a few notes:

Make sure SSID, team number and passcode was set right

6ghz light only lights up on connection, not when it is configured
